message_1:
A sports team has 10 players and wants to choose a captain and 2 co-captains. How many ways can they do this if any player can be captain but only certain players can be co-captains? 

Let's say player X and player Y are the only ones eligible to be co-captains. How many ways can the captain and 2 co-captains be chosen if player X and player Y must be among the chosen players?
message_2:
Since player X and player Y must be among the chosen players, one of them will be the captain and the other will be a co-captain. There are 2 ways to choose the captain (either X or Y). 

After choosing the captain, there are 8 remaining players (10 players - 1 captain - 1 co-captain). We need to choose 1 more co-captain from these 8 players. There are 8 ways to choose the second co-captain.

So, the total number of ways to choose the captain and 2 co-captains with the given condition is 2 (ways to choose the captain) * 8 (ways to choose the second co-captain) = 16 ways.
